It seems pretty clear that the NDA is weaker this time than last. With the exception of Bihar, it's hard to see where they are materially stronger than last time. And even there, considering they won 31 out of 40 seats, it's likely not to lead to a spike in won seats. Meanwhile, across the Hindi belt, they should face significant challenges, especially in UP, where they're facing a two-way fight from the INC, which is focusing on upper-caste voters, and the BSP-SP which is focusing on Dalits, OBCs and Muslims.  Though their last election looked pretty decisive, with a majority for the BJP alone, that they can only lose 50 seats while still holding onto a majority makes it seem fairly tenuous. Big picture, in retrospect, 2014 was a perfect storm; a popular national leader, with the tailwind of anti-incumbency after the INC won two terms despite not having deep roots, and facing a disorganized opposition, especially in UP. Modi is still popular, but now has to deal with some of the challenges of having an actual record, and the beginnings of a bit of his own anti-incumbency. Unlike the last election, which looked and felt like a blowout, this feels like a much tighter election. The only reason I'm nodding at all to Modi is that I suspect that if the NDA gets close to 272 but not quite there, he would be the obvious candidate to be the PM. The NDA would probably have to be below 260 for another candidate, whether Rahul or Nitish or someone like that, replaces him.

When looking solely at polling estimation data for the 2019 general elections in data, it is evident that Modi has an edge over other candidates. Polling data shows 62% support for Modi and only 32% support for the next runner-up, Rahul Gandhi (1). From this data alone Modi seems to be the obvious choice of the Indian population with very weak opposition. 
Additionally, the approval ratings for Modi have been very high throughout his time in office. The approval percentages have ranged from 88% to 63% throughout his first term as Prime Minister (2). This further cements his position, making it easier for him to win against competitors. 
Modi's current policy and global trends also increase the likelihood of his re-election. For example, Modi's policies have generally leaned towards populism and nationalism for the Indian people (3). Given the current global trend for nationalist leaders and sentiment, it would be likely that he be re-elected. 
Lastly, Modi's recent confrontation with Pakistan, India's long term rival, has boosted his approval ratings and has made him a very appealing choice for those in India. (4) 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2019_Indian_general_election#Next_Prime_Minister

Modi's approval ratings have risen following the 'vicotry' over the conflict with Pakistan in February (1). Modi will likely remain in power because rather than choosing an entirely religious platform, his campaign platform is one of nationalism. This message unites the some of the ideologically different Hindu populations as Modi is not seen as an ideologue nor does he appear to "pamper the minorities" (2). 
There are, however, still several economic questions that Modi must address. Unemployment in India is rising and the country's youths are moving into cities for  education and job opportunities. Unfortunately, there is a shortage of jobs, so there are more qualified individuals than there are vacancies. 
In rural parts of India, support for Modi is expected to stay strong because communities have benefited from cheaper cooking gas and electricity, as well as access to toilets and more schools (3). 
Another sign pointing towards Modi's expected success is the global trend of growing nationalism. While the opposition party in India has some support, the power of that party (called Congress) remains within one family - the Gandhi's. The public has resisted this form of contemporary monarchy (in more countries than just India), and have responded with the election of nationalist leaders, such as Modi.

This is an update to my previous forecasts (where I addressed seat number trends; opinion polls; the recent state elections; and economic factors). GOOGLE TRENDS DATA
Thanks to @patrickmeehan5 for giving me this idea a little while ago. I took a look at Google trends data for Indian elections. First I checked my own country (Australia - similar parliamentary system) and it looks like search terms for party leaders did a pretty good job of predicting elections (although with a few caveats, as our own political system has its own issues). Then I checked India's 2009 and 2014 elections - trend data was higher for the winning candidate in both elections. (Before that, it was unclear - but it's reasonable to think that signals would be less clear as technology was less developed.) Right now, Modi is ahead of Gandhi in the trends, and this is consistent over the past 6 months. This is evidence in favour of a Modi victory. It's difficult to tell how much stock to put in this analysis. Without a systematic analysis (e.g. including other countries), it's hard to get a feel for the success rate of this method. Regardless, it bumps up my prediction by a conservative 4% or so. LABOR STRIKE One thing to think about is the strikes protesting against Modi's labor policies. By all estimates this was a huge strike (in the tens of millions) and it is reasonable to think that this will translate to voting against Modi for people who sympathize with the strikers. (For strike details see e.g. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/02/indian-workers-strike-in-fight-for-higher-wages). Obviously tens of millions of voters would be a deciding factor in a close election. I'll have a think about how to incorporate this information.

Update to my previous analysis: Correlation between NDA seats and UPA seats
    • In an earlier analysis, I estimated distributions for the amount of seats we can expect each party to receive. These distributions, as with all mathematical models, were simplifications of reality. In this update, I address one simplification – the fact that seats lost by NDA might go to UPA. Here I’m mostly looking at the elections 1991 – 2014 (before that, BJP hadn’t really gained momentum). Also, I’m looking at coalitions rather than parties – the reason is simply that I have already produced models for coalitions, not for parties.
    • There’s a strong correlation between INC and BJP seats (0.933). Taken together, the two coalitions take, on average, 78% of seats.
    • So we can think about the election in this way – imagine a world where INC starts with 100% of seats. Then the election involves people going in and casting their votes, and for each non-NDA vote, we subtract a seat from NDA. On average, 78% of votes subtracted from NDA in this way will be assigned to UPA. The other 22% will be assigned to the non-coalition parties.
    • In my earlier analysis, I arrived at the following distribution for the NDA seats we can expect at the next election. (I did create two distributions for NDA, but after analysing state polls, I’m wary of using poll data.)
      NDA ~ N(258, 542)
    • So if we model NDA as above, we can model UPA as dependent on NDA. Simply, NDA takes 78% of the seats that NDA does not get:
      UPA = (543 – NDA) * 0.78
    • In this model, I’m going to assume that a coalition with more seats will win the election. This is an oversimplification of how minority governments form, but it’s approximately correct – and good enough for the model. Where NDA wins 238 seats, UPA wins 238 seats. Where NDA is more successful, UPA is less successful, vice-versa. So, if NDA has more than 238 seats, NDA will form government, and where NDA has fewer than 238 seats, UPA will form government.
    • (Note: In this model, there’s no real need to model majority governments and minority governments separately.)
    • So the steps from here are simple: all we have to do is, using the NDA distribution above, calculate the probability that NDA will win 238 or more seats. This probability (you can calculate using a spreadsheet) is 64.44%.
    • The probability changes very little if you play around with the total % of seats taken by the two coalitions.
    • So which of my approaches is better? This captures a part of reality that my previous analysis does not catch – although it has its own simplifications, it feels better than my previous analysis. If we assume that popularity is proportional to seats won in both national and state elections, BJP’s popularity has declined by about 36.08% of seats (excluding areas with <5 seats), which equates to 62.79 national seats (not excluding anything). If this translated directly, BJP would move from 282 seats in 2014 to 282-63=219 seats in 2019 (a loss of about 23%). NDA would move from 336 seats in 2014 to 273 seats (63 fewer) or 261 seats (23% fewer). A majority for a coalition is 272. So, based on these numbers, it doesn’t look like NDA is in danger at all. Even if we subtract the 16-20 seats based on defections away from NDA, we end up with 241 seats at worst for NDA (based on these numbers). This means that the trends we are seeing do cause a weaker margin for NDA, but they do not mean NDA is no longer capable of forming government. So how can UPA win? An unexpected landslide victory is how. The 2014 election should make us think twice about discounting the probability of an unexpected turnaround. But 2014 is really the first time it happened since 1989 – at every other election, the # seats won by a given party was close to the previous election. This makes the base rate of an unexpected turnaround 1 in 8, or 12.5%. We can adjust this up – say by 5% or 10%, because INC was very popular before 2014, and it’s reasonable for a landslide to be more likely directly after a previous landslide. Every way I’ve looked at the data, NDA has been far more likely to win (generally about 70%). The fact that I’ve reached the same conclusion in a number of ways gives me more faith in this. I can only imagine NDA losing if UPA makes a comeback, which I think is 22.5% likely at most. So I’m going to call this 77.5% for NDA winning, meaning 76.7% for Modi being sworn in again.

I did some more number crunching on a) state elections and b) predictive power of polls. Conclusions are at the bottom of the post. I haven't yet thought about how to incorporate this into my forecast - the first section is a strong point in favour of a BJP victory, and the second section (at worst) cancels out a point of evidence from my previous analysis. STATE ELECTIONS In the 16 elections in 2017 and 2018, BJP won 8 and lost 5. In the subset of 9 elections that were in 2018, BJP won 2 and INC won 4. So, taking 2017 and 2018 as a whole, BJP clearly performed better than INC. In just 2018, BJP performed (very marginally) worse than INC. But what about if we consider the size of the states? Some of these states only contribute 1 seat to the national elections, while Uttar Pradesh contributes 80 seats. So not all state election victories should be weighted equally. (Keep in mind there are 543 elected seats.) I summed the number of national election seats for which each party won the corresponding state election. This number is 122 for BJP and 106 for INC.
    • Taking just the 2017 elections, the number is 119 for BJP and 13 for INC.
    • Taking just the 2018 elections, the number is 3 for BJP and 93 for INC. So what’s going on here? Has BJP’s popularity absolutely plummeted, from literally 119 to 3, over the course of one year? Or did the 2018 elections just happen to line up with areas where BJP has become less popular?
    • If BJP’s popularity has plummeted: we would expect to see a swap from BJP domination to INC domination in the state seats where BJP won the national elections. In other words, we would expect low correlation between state control and national control.
    • If the 2018 elections happen to favour INC: we would expect to see less change in domination, and INC domination in the national seats where INC won the state elections. In other words, we would expect high correlation between state control and national control. Also, we would expect most 2018 elections to have happened in places where INC had a higher proportion of national seats. For this analysis, I excluded two areas (Nagaland and Tripura) where there were 0 seats won between BJP and INC in either the state or national elections. 78% of areas with a higher BJP proportion of state seats also had a higher BJP proportion of national seats. (The total if 64% if you only count states where BJP ultimately formed government.) This means that only 22% of areas that preferred BJP in the national elections changed their minds. So what if this trend continues, and BJP loses 22% of its national seats? They’d be down from 282 in 2014 to 220 in 2019. Adding this to the ~60 seats that BJP’s allies in NDA usually win, we’d expect 280 seats to BJP – which meets the majority requirement of 272. Alternatively, if NDA as a whole takes a hit of 22%, they would end up with 262 seats, which is just shy of the majority requirement – but still very close, and they would be likely to form a minority government. About the election years – the 2018 elections covered areas where INC already had an average of 45% of national seats. The 2017 elections covered areas where INC already had an average of 30% of national seats. So, it seems that INC was predisposed to fare better in 2018 than in 2017. PREDICTIVE POWER OF OPINION POLLS I looked at the predictions of the 10 state polls that I could find for 2017-18 state elections. (That is, the polls corresponding to 10 state elections – I considered all polls for a given period as equal.) For each polling period, I generated a 95% confidence interval for the average number of seats predicted for each party. Of 20 intervals (10 for BJP, 10 for INC), 9 contained the actual number of seats; 4 were close; and 7 were well off. Furthermore, only 5 of the 10 averaged polls correctly predicted which party would obtain more seats. From this, it looks like looking at polls to see who will win an election is no better than random. Looking at the actual number of seats, using a 95% confidence interval, was accurate or close-to-accurate for 13/20 polls. This might be chance, or it might be better-than-random – but even if it’s the latter, it’s not much better. I’m hesitant about extrapolating these results to national elections – I want more data for past national elections. TO CONCLUDE     • BJP is experiencing a small decline in popularity, but it isn’t collapsing. The state elections in 2018 favoured INC to begin with.
    • The state polls have little or no predictive power, but I haven’t got enough data to say whether this is true for the national polls too.

First I will answer the question “What is the probability of Modi’s coalition, NDA, forming a government?” I will address non-election concerns at the bottom. I’m happy to reproduce any graphs/tables/analyses. My quantitative analysis will use statistics in ways they were never designed for. 
Mos Def said “Push too hard, even numbers got limits” - but I think what I’ve done here is fine within this context. I have two methods for predicting how many seats NDA will win – extrapolating time series, and extrapolating poll data.
Note that, in the up-coming election, 543 seats are being contested. 272 seats is a majority. A hung parliament occurs if no coalition can achieve 272 seats. Time series of seats for NDA:
    • The time series of national elections from 1996 – 2014 show that the correlation between BJP’s seats and NDA’s seats is extremely high. But a correlation between BJP’s seats and the non-BJP NDA seats is only about 30%. A scatterplot shows no clear pattern. So, it seems that the non-BJP parties in NDA usually get about 59 seats (min: 39, max: 87).
    • The pattern of BJP’s own seats over time shows a steady rise, a peak in the 98-99 elections, a steady fall, and then the enormous rise in the 2014 elections. It’s hard to project this data, so there are a couple of choices:
        ◦ Ignore 2014, and assume that BJP will receive about as many seats as in 2009 (116 seats),
        ◦ Place the number of seats of BJP somewhere around the peak in 2014 (282 seats, probably lower).
    • So the distribution of seats from NDA will look like:
        ◦ A mean around the middle of the 2009 and 2014 results, plus the 59 allied seats = 258 seats.
        ◦ A minimum at the 2009 election, plus a low of 39 allied seats = 155 seats.
        ◦ A maximum at the 2014 election, plus a high of 87 allied seats = 369 seats. I’d like to moderate this down to the 320-350 range, because a landslide victory and a landslide number of allies in combination seems extremely unlikely. My gut instinct says that NDA will almost certainly not go much higher than its 2014 victory, which was at 316 seats. So let’s call the maximum 330 seats.
        ◦ This means that this analysis generates a roughly symmetrical distribution of:
            ▪ Min 155 seats
            ▪ Mean 258 seats
            ▪ Max 369 seats
        ◦ We can assume that the distribution is roughly bell-shaped (i.e. normally distributed). The way that normal distributions work is it’s extremely unlikely for events to fall in the far tails – so we can simply specify that 155 and 369 seats are within the realm of possibility but not likely, or about 2 standard deviations from the mean. This way, we can estimate the probability of NDA obtaining a given number of seats.
        ◦ The distance between the mean (258) and the two extremes (155, 369) is 103 and 111, so we can go with 107 as the average distance. If 107 is two standard deviations from the mean, then one standard deviation is about 54. So the distribution looks like:
          NDA ~ N(258, 542)
          In English, this means that the number of seats that NDA could obtain is normally distributed with a mean of 258 seats and a standard deviation of 54 seats.
        ◦ 272 seats are needed for a majority. This distribution actually means that NDA’s mean is a minority. The normal cumulative distribution function (the NORM.DIST function in LibreOffice Calc or probably similar in Microsoft Excel) shows that the probability of getting 271.5 seats or fewer is 59.9%, so the probability of NDA getting a majority is 40.1%. Repeating for INC:
    • I’ll keep the allied seats obeying the same distribution (39-59-87). This is because UPA just has less data, but also because of the changing nature of coalitions – especially given the latest defections away from NDA.
    • Using the same methods, we end up with a distribution of:
        ◦ Min 44 plus 39 seats = 83 seats; but moderated again by 30-50 seats to, say, 123 seats
        ◦ Mean 125 plus 59 seats = 184 seats
        ◦ Max 206 plus 87 seats = 293 seats
    • So the normal distribution looks like:
      UPA ~ N(184, 542) Time series of seats from polls:
    • The only polling data I can access is the polls before the 2014 election and the polls for the current election. I’ll use the data for expected seats, not percentage votes.
    • The data for the 2014 election showed a pattern of divergence over time, with NDA becoming more popular and UPA becoming less popular. No poll predicted the magnitude of NDA’s victory, but the polls immediately before the election were actually quite close.
    • The polls for this year show a convergence, with the popular NDA falling and the unpopular UPA regaining popularity.
    • NDA seems to be slowly declining in popularity since 1 Jan 2018. Taking the poll data from this point onwards shows the following regression line, where x = days since 1 Jan 2018, and y = expected seats:
      y = -0.1177x + 303.82
    • Extrapolating this trend to 1 May 2019 (approximate date of elections) means that NDA is expected to win 246.7 seats, which is shy of the 272 needed for a majority.
    • Another way of looking the data is to imagine that there will be no change in popularity between now and election date – in other words, we can take the number of expected seats from the most recent polls as our estimate of the seats that will be won in reality.
    • NDA’s popularity seems to have been relatively constant since Apr 2018. The sample of expected seats from Apr 2018 to today has a mean of 269.4 and a sample standard deviation of 21.68.
    • We can even carry across the sample standard deviation to the regression line above. This gives us two distributions for the expected number of seats:
      NDA ~ N(246.7, 21.682)
      NDA ~ N(269.4, 21.682)
    • To produce an average of these distributions, we can consider the mean as the mean of the means (haha):
      NDA ~ N(258.1, 21.682)
    • I’m absolutely stunned that the mean here (258.1) and the mean in the time series analysis above (258) are the same.
    • Using the sample cumulative distribution function as earlier, the probability of getting 271.5 seats or fewer is 73.2%, so the probability of NDA getting a majority is 26.8%. Repeating for UPA:
    • The regression equation is:
      y = 0.09536x + 172.12
      This extrapolates such that the expected number of seats for UPA on 1 May 2019 is 172.
    • The sample of expected seats from Apr 2018 to today has a mean of 157 and a sample standard deviation of 47.77.
    • Thus the two distributions for the expected number of seats are:
      UPA ~ N(157, 47.772)
      UPA ~ N(172.12, 47.772)
    • The mean of the means means that:
      UPA ~ N(164.56, 47.772) To summarise, here are the four distributions that I have generated. I’ll give them all a subscript to denote whether they were obtained using time series of seats (t) or by extrapolating poll data (p).
    • NDAt ~ N(258, 542) [based on seats over time]
    • NDAp ~ N(258.1, 21.682) [based on extrapolating poll data]
    • UPAt ~ N(184, 542) [based on seats over time]
    • UPAp ~ N(164.56, 47.772) [based on extrapolating poll data] These four distributions can be used to calculate the probability that:
    • NDA will obtain 272 or more seats
        ◦ 40.1% and 26.8%, average to 33.48% for an NDA majority
    • UPA will obtain 272 or more seats
        ◦ 5.26% and 3.34%, average to 4.30% for a UPA majority
    • The remaining probability is 62.2% for a hung parliament. What if there is a hung parliament?
    • Firstly, given the situation of a hung parliament, it’s difficult to forecast how negotiations will turn out. Instead, I will use the number of seats that each coalition gets as a proxy for negotiating power / the ability to form a minority government.
    • What’s the probability of NDA having more seats than UPA? The following numbers are generated from many observations taken at random from the normal distributions.
        ◦ Using the time series distributions: NDA gets more seats (but not a majority) 43.6% of the time, and UPA 12.7% of the time.
        ◦ Using the poll distributions: NDA 71.2%, and UPA 3.1%.
        ◦ Using time series for NDA and poll for UPA: NDA 55%, and UPA 8%.
        ◦ Using poll for NDA and time series for UPA: NDA 66.5%, and UPA 4.6%.
        ◦ If you standardize each pair then calculate the averages for each party, you get: 
          Given that there is a hung parliament, NDA is 88.53% to get more seats but not have a majority, and UPA is 11.47% to get more seats but not have a majority.
        ◦ Also note: In the situation of a hung parliament, NDA is, on average, 43.94 seats ahead of UPA.
    • Secondly, I want to think about the defections that have happened from NDA recently.
        ◦ The major supporting parties for BJP in 2014 were Shiv Sena (18 seats); Telugu Desam Party (16 seats); Lok Janshakti Party (6 seats); Shiromani Akali Dal (4 seats) and Rashtriya Lok Samata Party (3 seats).
        ◦ Telugu Desam Party defected from the NDA in March 2018. Rashtriya Lok Samata Party defected from the NDA in December 2018.
        ◦ [INC’s major supporters in 2014 were National Congress Party (6 seats); and Rashtriya Janata Dal (4 seats). Shiv Sena supported INC in 2009. INC’s biggest supporter in 2009 (All India Trinamool Congress; 19 seats) is no longer part of UPA, but rather the Third Front.]
        ◦ Telugu Desam Party’s defection in particular is a loss of 16 seats – given that a hung parliament is the most probably situation, this is a massive swing towards the UPA. Even assuming that Shiv Sena continues to support NDA, a hung parliament situation is less favourable for NDA than the above numbers would indicate.
        ◦ I’m not sure what the best way to incorporate this information is – perhaps it’s best just to subtract 16 from each of the above NDA distributions and add 16 to each of the UPA distributions.
            ▪ NDAt2 ~ N(243, 542) [based on seats over time]
            ▪ NDAp2 ~ N(243.1, 21.682) [based on extrapolating poll data]
            ▪ UPAt2 ~ N(200, 542) [based on seats over time]
            ▪ UPAp2 ~ N(180.56, 47.772) [based on extrapolating poll data]
        ◦ Using the time series distributions: NDA gets more seats (but not a majority) 44.9% of the time, and UPA 21.1% of the time.
        ◦ Using the poll distributions: NDA 78.9%, and UPA 10.6%.
        ◦ Using time series for NDA and poll for UPA: NDA 51.3%, and UPA 15.4%.
        ◦ Using poll for NDA and time series for UPA: NDA 65.8%, and UPA 14.1%.
        ◦ If you standardize each pair then calculate the averages for each party, you get: 
          Given that there is a hung parliament, NDA is 78.87% to get more seats but not have a majority, and UPA is 21.14% to get more seats but not have a majority.
        ◦ In a hung parliament even considering defections, NDA maintains a 24.71 average seat lead.
        ◦ My gut instinct says that these numbers underestimate the effects of party defections. I think that the probabilities of each party’s success in a hung parliament are closer to half-half than this above analysis makes out. So I might roll with 60% for NDA and 40% for UPA. (I’ll consider both, but I have more faith in this gut instinct set of numbers.) Combining everything
    • NDA majority: 33.48%
    • UPA majority: 4.30%
    • NDA minority government: 62.2% x 78.87% = 49.06% (numbers at face value)
      OR  62.2% x 60% = 37.32% (gut instinct)
    • UPA minority government: 62.2% x 21.14% = 13.15% (numbers at face value)
      OR 62.2% x 40% = 24.88% (gut instinct) Therefore:
    • NDA government = 33.48% + 49.06% = 82.54%
      OR 33.48% + 37.32% = 70.80%
    • [UPA government = 17.45%, or 29.2%] Below I have outlined a rough analysis by which economic factors can predict whether a government is re-elected. This is a total probability for re-election; it can’t predict the number of seats. Consider it as separate to the analysis above. Economic factors:
    • There’s a good analysis here (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/measuring-the-effect-of-the-economy-on-elections/) on predicting elections using economic effects. The author calls for using a) many economic factors; b) broad economic factors; c) regularly updated factors.
    • I will use the following data sets (available from World Bank https://databank.worldbank.org/data/reports.aspx?source=2&country=IND):
        ◦ GDP per capita growth (annual %)
        ◦ Inflation, consumer prices (annual %)
        ◦ Inflation, GDP deflator: linked series (annual %)
        ◦ Gross national expenditure (% of GDP) (note: I subtracted 100 from this, to keep it on the same scale as the others. Doesn’t change results.)
    • Note on inflation: Although I do have a qualification in economics, but haven’t the foggiest idea which of these two measures of inflation is more important as an election predictor. I’ll average them for the years where both are available.
    • I won’t use unemployment. While unemployment strikes me as important, World Bank data estimates that India’s total unemployment is remarkably constant around 3.5%, with very little year-to-year variation. So this variable won’t really affect the model.
    • I ignore the 1991 election, because the previous election was won by National Front but this coalition fell apart after their term. I ignore the 1998 election, because the 1996 election was won by BJP but they left office due to instability. (The 1999 election covers this time period just fine anyway, so I’m counting 1998 and 1999 as one election.)
    • I generated two models. The first model’s response variable is the number of seats given to the ruling party at the next election. This model had extremely poor explanatory power, so I have decided not to use it in the analysis. The second model is a logistic model where the response variable is binary, whether or not the ruling party was returned to power. This second model had much better (still not amazing – but better) explanatory power.
    • Long-story short: the model is actually quite strong, given the noisy and not-that-good data. Out of 7 elections used to generate the model, and crudely dividing the probabilities into <50% means no and >50% means yes, the model is successful at 5. (This is a measurement of model fit, not predictive power.)
    • Using data up to 2017 (so only missing 2018 data), the model predicts a 30.7% probability of a change in government. In other words, it places the probability of BJP being re-elected at 69.29%. Combining the seat analysis with the economic analysis:
    • Average of 70.80% and 69.29% is 70.045%. So my estimate for NDA’s return to government after the 2019 elections is 70.045%. Now let’s address other election concerns.
    • Modi is 68 years old, and he may die before being sworn into government. The mortality tables indicate that the probability of a 68-year old man in India dying before the end of May is 1.09%.
    • It’s possible for Modi to leave the leadership of the party …
        ◦ … by the party’s request: I’m going to consider this probability negligible, because Modi is extremely popular compared to anybody else who could lead the party. Past polls on Wikipedia have even got separate entries for BJP’s success under some other leader, which is always given as lower.
        ◦ … if it turns out he’s committed some crime: I don’t know what the probability of this is. How many Asian heads-of-party are kicked from the position due to criminal proceedings? It did sorta happen to the head of INC recently, but I’m going to assume that the probability for it happening to Modi in the next few months is negligible. (Clearly more work will improve my estimate here.)
        ◦ … if he decides to leave politics: In Hamilton, King George III said “I wasn’t aware that was something a person could do.” What’s the chance that Modi decides that leading India to greatness isn’t for him, and decides to retire to the Pacific to pursue his career as an athlete/artist/model? Again, seems unlikely. Given my thoughts here, I’m going to place the chance of Modi being sworn in as the chance of NDA returning to government multiplied by the probability of Modi not dying.
    • 70.045*(100-1.09) = 69.282% The most important factors that would change my analysis are a) new polls that are very different from last time, b) the release of 2018 economic data in a format comparable with the World Bank, c) major changes in Modi’s life.

Current opinion polling seems to suggest a slight edge to Modi's BJP. India's Prime Minister tends toward a cult of personality, and Modi is preferred over Rahul Gandhi by a significant double digit margin. There doesn't seem to be other likely contenders. While fragmentation might led to a hung parliament, the most likely scenario seems to be he'll plug into Hindu nationalism and get himself in again. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2019_Indian_general_election

bumping up a bit after reading this positive write-up re the Indian economy for 2019, though I'd say the wild card remains crop prices https://www.businesstoday.in/current/economy-politics/general-elections-us-dollar-strength-and-oil-prices-to-direct-rupee-report/story/305390.html

Going to go a bit lower than consensus - I don't think India is the easiest place to poll, we don't have a lot of polls to begin with, and the last set of elections were not especially favourable for the BJP, though that won't necessarily translate to the next general election. A lot of fairly random economic factors could spell serious trouble for Modi: vide this story about widespread discontent amongst farmers due to low onion prices https://www.indiatoday.in/india/story/onion-farmers-prices-maharashtra-narendra-modi-2019-lok-sabha-elections-1418772-2018-12-28. It may sound trivial to Western ears, but as the article notes, this sort of thing has a big track record of turning out to be the difference-maker in prior Indian elections. India is also a big oil importer and quite vulnerable to a sudden spike in oil prices, should that occur between now and April/May. He's the clear front-runner, but a few factors combine to pull me down towards 50% vs the crowd

The December state election results notwithstanding, the BJP and Modi have built a strong election machine and given the results in many other election in the last few years I think Modi wins another term.
The December state elections are telling and I think Indians as a whole think they can do better, considering the corruption charges and slow of economic growth.
